maml:description.maml:para: Adds a value to a custom field in IPAM.
The Add-IpamCustomValue cmdlet adds a value to a custom field in IP Address Management (IPAM). You can add a value to a built-in field or user-defined custom field.

Specifies the name of a custom field. The cmdlet adds the value that you specify for the Value parameter to the custom field. You can specify the localized server name or the non-localized name of a built-in, multivalued custom field.
Specifies a value to add to the custom field.

Runs the cmdlet as a background job. Use this parameter to run commands that take a long time to complete. The cmdlet immediately returns an object that represents the job and then displays the command prompt. You can continue to work in the session while the job completes. To manage the job, use the *-Job cmdlets. To get the job results, use the Receive-Job cmdlet. For more information about Windows PowerShell® background jobs, see about_Jobs.

Runs the cmdlet in a remote session or on a remote computer. Enter a computer name or a session object, such as the output of a New-CimSession or Get-CimSession cmdlet. The default is the current session on the local computer.
Returns an object representing the item with which you are working. By default, this cmdlet does not generate any output.

Specifies the maximum number of concurrent operations that can be established to run the cmdlet. If this parameter is omitted or a value of 0 is entered, then Windows PowerShell® calculates an optimum throttle limit for the cmdlet based on the number of CIM cmdlets that are running on the computer. The throttle limit applies only to the current cmdlet, not to the session or to the computer.
Prompts you for confirmation before running the cmdlet.
Shows what would happen if the cmdlet runs. The cmdlet is not run.

Runs the cmdlet as a background job. Use this parameter to run commands that take a long time to complete. The cmdlet immediately returns an object that represents the job and then displays the command prompt. You can continue to work in the session while the job completes. To manage the job, use the *-Job cmdlets. To get the job results, use the Receive-Job cmdlet. For more information about Windows PowerShell® background jobs, see about_Jobs.

Runs the cmdlet in a remote session or on a remote computer. Enter a computer name or a session object, such as the output of a New-CimSession or Get-CimSession cmdlet. The default is the current session on the local computer.

Specifies the name of a custom field. The cmdlet adds the value that you specify for the Value parameter to the custom field. You can specify the localized server name or the non-localized name of a built-in, multivalued custom field.
Returns an object representing the item with which you are working. By default, this cmdlet does not generate any output.

Specifies the maximum number of concurrent operations that can be established to run the cmdlet. If this parameter is omitted or a value of 0 is entered, then Windows PowerShell® calculates an optimum throttle limit for the cmdlet based on the number of CIM cmdlets that are running on the computer. The throttle limit applies only to the current cmdlet, not to the session or to the computer.
Specifies a value to add to the custom field.
Prompts you for confirmation before running the cmdlet.
Shows what would happen if the cmdlet runs. The cmdlet is not run.
This object contains an IPAM custom value.

dev:remarks.maml:para: This command adds the custom value DivMain01 to the user defined custom field named Divisions.

command:example.maml:title: Example 2: Add a custom value to a user defined custom field
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\>Add-IpamCustomValue -Name "Divisions" -Value "DivMain01" -PassThru Value Category CustomField ------------------------------------------------------------ DivMain01 UserDefined Divisions

dev:remarks.maml:para: This command adds the custom value DivMain01 to the user defined custom field named Divisions. The command includes the PassThru parameter, so it displays results to the console.

command:example.maml:title: Example 3: Add a custom value to a built-in custom field
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\>Add-IpamCustomValue -Name "ServiceInstance" -Value "vmm1.contoso.com" -PassThru Value Category CustomField ------------------------------------------------------------ vmm1.contoso.com UserDefined ServiceInstance

dev:remarks.maml:para: This command adds the custom value vmm1.contoso.com to the built-in custom field named ServiceInstance. The command includes the PassThru parameter, so it displays results to the console.

maml:description.maml:para: Removes a custom value from IPAM.

The Remove-IpamCustomValue cmdlet removes a set of values from a multivalued custom field. Specify the Name parameter and the Value parameter. If you specify values that do not exist in the custom field, the cmdlet removes the values that do exist and returns an error that specifies the values that it did not remove because the values do not exist. You cannot remove custom values that are assigned to IPAM objects. You cannot remove built-in values for built-in custom fields.
Specifies the name of a custom field. The cmdlet removes the value that you specify for the Value parameter from the custom field.
Specifies a set of values to remove from the custom field.

Runs the cmdlet as a background job. Use this parameter to run commands that take a long time to complete. The cmdlet immediately returns an object that represents the job and then displays the command prompt. You can continue to work in the session while the job completes. To manage the job, use the *-Job cmdlets. To get the job results, use the Receive-Job cmdlet. For more information about Windows PowerShell® background jobs, see about_Jobs.

Runs the cmdlet in a remote session or on a remote computer. Enter a computer name or a session object, such as the output of a New-CimSession or Get-CimSession cmdlet. The default is the current session on the local computer.
Forces the command to run without asking for user confirmation.
Returns an object representing the item with which you are working. By default, this cmdlet does not generate any output.

Specifies the maximum number of concurrent operations that can be established to run the cmdlet. If this parameter is omitted or a value of 0 is entered, then Windows PowerShell® calculates an optimum throttle limit for the cmdlet based on the number of CIM cmdlets that are running on the computer. The throttle limit applies only to the current cmdlet, not to the session or to the computer.
Prompts you for confirmation before running the cmdlet.
Shows what would happen if the cmdlet runs. The cmdlet is not run.

Runs the cmdlet as a background job. Use this parameter to run commands that take a long time to complete. The cmdlet immediately returns an object that represents the job and then displays the command prompt. You can continue to work in the session while the job completes. To manage the job, use the *-Job cmdlets. To get the job results, use the Receive-Job cmdlet. For more information about Windows PowerShell® background jobs, see about_Jobs.

Runs the cmdlet in a remote session or on a remote computer. Enter a computer name or a session object, such as the output of a New-CimSession or Get-CimSession cmdlet. The default is the current session on the local computer.
Forces the command to run without asking for user confirmation.
Specifies the name of a custom field. The cmdlet removes the value that you specify for the Value parameter from the custom field.
Returns an object representing the item with which you are working. By default, this cmdlet does not generate any output.

Specifies the maximum number of concurrent operations that can be established to run the cmdlet. If this parameter is omitted or a value of 0 is entered, then Windows PowerShell® calculates an optimum throttle limit for the cmdlet based on the number of CIM cmdlets that are running on the computer. The throttle limit applies only to the current cmdlet, not to the session or to the computer.
Specifies a set of values to remove from the custom field.
Prompts you for confirmation before running the cmdlet.
Shows what would happen if the cmdlet runs. The cmdlet is not run.

command:example.maml:title: Example 1: Remove a value from a custom field
command:example.dev:code:
PS C:\> Remove-IpamCustomValue -Name "Building" -Value "Main01" Confirm
This command will permanently delete Custom Value Main01 of Custom Field Building from IPAM. Do you want to
continue?
[Y] Yes [N] No [S] Suspend [?] Help (default is "Y"): Y

dev:remarks.maml:para: This command removes the value named Main01 from the custom field named Building.

maml:description.maml:para: Changes a value for a custom field.

The Rename-IpamCustomValue cmdlet changes a value for a multivalued custom field. The cmdlet changes only the custom value. Associations between the custom field and other custom fields and assignments to other IPAM objects remain valid. You cannot change built-in values of built-in custom fields. The cmdlet results in an error if the value that you specify does not exist for the custom field that you specify.
Specifies the name of a custom field. The cmdlet changes the value from the custom field that you specify for the Value parameter.
Specifies a custom value. The cmdlet changes this value to the value that you specify for the NewValue parameter.
Specifies a value to replace the custom field value that you specify for the Value parameter.

Runs the cmdlet as a background job. Use this parameter to run commands that take a long time to complete. The cmdlet immediately returns an object that represents the job and then displays the command prompt. You can continue to work in the session while the job completes. To manage the job, use the *-Job cmdlets. To get the job results, use the Receive-Job cmdlet. For more information about Windows PowerShell® background jobs, see about_Jobs.

Runs the cmdlet in a remote session or on a remote computer. Enter a computer name or a session object, such as the output of a New-CimSession or Get-CimSession cmdlet. The default is the current session on the local computer.
Forces the command to run without asking for user confirmation.
Returns an object representing the item with which you are working. By default, this cmdlet does not generate any output.

Specifies the maximum number of concurrent operations that can be established to run the cmdlet. If this parameter is omitted or a value of 0 is entered, then Windows PowerShell® calculates an optimum throttle limit for the cmdlet based on the number of CIM cmdlets that are running on the computer. The throttle limit applies only to the current cmdlet, not to the session or to the computer.
Prompts you for confirmation before running the cmdlet.
Shows what would happen if the cmdlet runs. The cmdlet is not run.

Runs the cmdlet as a background job. Use this parameter to run commands that take a long time to complete. The cmdlet immediately returns an object that represents the job and then displays the command prompt. You can continue to work in the session while the job completes. To manage the job, use the *-Job cmdlets. To get the job results, use the Receive-Job cmdlet. For more information about Windows PowerShell® background jobs, see about_Jobs.

Runs the cmdlet in a remote session or on a remote computer. Enter a computer name or a session object, such as the output of a New-CimSession or Get-CimSession cmdlet. The default is the current session on the local computer.
Forces the command to run without asking for user confirmation.
Specifies the name of a custom field. The cmdlet changes the value from the custom field that you specify for the Value parameter.
Specifies a value to replace the custom field value that you specify for the Value parameter.
Returns an object representing the item with which you are working. By default, this cmdlet does not generate any output.

Specifies the maximum number of concurrent operations that can be established to run the cmdlet. If this parameter is omitted or a value of 0 is entered, then Windows PowerShell® calculates an optimum throttle limit for the cmdlet based on the number of CIM cmdlets that are running on the computer. The throttle limit applies only to the current cmdlet, not to the session or to the computer.
Specifies a custom value. The cmdlet changes this value to the value that you specify for the NewValue parameter.
Prompts you for confirmation before running the cmdlet.
Shows what would happen if the cmdlet runs. The cmdlet is not run.
Represents a custom metadata field in IPAM Server.

command:example.maml:title: Example 1: Change a value for a custom field
command:example.dev:code:
PS C:\> Rename-IpamCustomValue -Name "Building" -Value "NorthB3" -NewValue "MainB3" -PassThru Value Category CustomField
----- -------- -----------
NorthB2 UserDefined Building

dev:remarks.maml:para: This command changes the value from NorthB3 to MainB3 for the custom field named Building.
